Key Arguments: The terminology of 'misinformation and disinformation' implies a single version of truth determined by the government or ACMA.
Censorship of divergent views and restriction on free speech pose a greater threat to democracy and society than misinformation.
Concerns about privacy invasion and government overreach through monitoring and data collection.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation are subjective and could label individuals unfairly.
The bill could be misused to restrict free speech and debate, which are essential to democracy.
Main Themes: Subjectivity in defining misinformation and disinformation
Notable Quotes: The censorship of divergent points of view and the restriction on free speech would be a far greater threat to the safety and wellbeing of Australian and our democracy, society and economy than any posed by alleged ‘misinformation and disinformation’.
This Bill seems a step towards totalitarianism and this is complete antithesis to the freedoms currently enjoyed by all Australians.
